review.title: Fast Online Clustering with Randomized Skeleton Sets
review.abstract: We present a new fast online clustering algorithm that reliably recovers arbitrary-shaped data clusters in high throughout data streams. Unlike the existing state-of-the-art online clustering methods based on k-means or k-medoid, it does not make any restrictive generative assumptions. In addition, in contrast to existing nonparametric clustering techniques such as DBScan or DenStream, it gives provable theoretical guarantees. To achieve fast clustering, we propose to represent each cluster by a skeleton set which is updated continuously as new data is seen. A skeleton set consists of weighted samples from the data where weights encode local densities. The size of each skeleton set is adapted according to the cluster geometry. The proposed technique automatically detects the number of clusters and is robust to outliers. The algorithm works for the infinite data stream where more than one pass over the data is not feasible. We provide theoretical guarantees on the quality of the clustering and also demonstrate its advantage over the existing state-of-the-art on several datasets.

metadata.title: Fast Online Clustering with Randomized Skeleton Sets

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In social networks, gathering and tracking clusters or communities is important for analyzing evolutionary patterns. In real-world applications, the number and shape of clusters can typically be unknown; existing online cluster methods with verifiable theoretical guarantees are primarily geared toward developing a good cluster algorithm; in real-world applications, the number and shape of clusters is typically unknown; and existing state-of-the-art cluster methods with verifiable theoretical guarantees are primarily geared toward developing a good cluster algorithm.

sections.heading: 2. Clustering Framework
sections.text: In this work, it is important to first define what constitutes a good cluster, since we are interested in retrieving arbitrarily shaped clusters. Traditional model-based techniques presuppose a global distance measure (e.g. L2 spacing in k-mean), which limits one to convex-shaped clusters. Instead, the proposed algorithm works in a non-parametric environment where clusters are defined by an intuitive notion of paths with "short edges." Two points tend to belong to the same cluster when there are many paths in the data neighbor curve, so that two consecutive points on each path are not "far" from each other. Of course, the total distance between two points can be large, but they can still be in the same cluster. Such a setting makes it possible to look at many complicated cluster shapes. To emphasize it, the idea of the neighborhood graph is to understand the cluster definition that we implicitly use in this work.

sections.heading: 2.1. Skeleton-based Online Clustering (SOC) Algorithm
sections.text: The key idea behind the SOC algorithm is to represent each cluster via a series of pseudorandom samples, called skeletal sets. (We assume that the number of clusters that can change over time are seen as new data.) Each skeletal set is a cluster and consists of a sample (vi1, v i hi) of all the points that belong to that cluster, along with some carefully selected random numbers (mi1, m hi) and weights (wi1, w hi hi hi). Thus, a skeletal set of elements is of the form: (vij, m i j j j, j j j j j j j) for j = 1, 2..., hi. Sometimes we also call {vi1, vihi} a skeletal set that should be clear from the context.

sections.heading: 3.1. Merging Lemma
sections.text: Since both theorems consider the saturation phase of the algorithm, in theoretical analysis, whenever we talk about the algorithm, we can actually assume that a point v weighing wv > 0 can be treated as equivalent to a collection of wv skeletal points of weight one (see: Description of the algorithm). Let us formulate the following problem: Lemma 3.1. Suppose that the algorithm at a given time t merges two clusters: P1 and P2 so that P1 contains a point of Ri and P2 a point of Rj for some i 6 = j. Then either: at least 1 of all skeletal points of P1 at a given time t are outliers or: at least 1 of all skeletal points of P2 at a given time t are outliers.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments
sections.text: We evaluated the performance of the proposed SOC algorithm using four synthetic data sets as shown in Figure 2 (left column), which contain data points in 20 dimensions; the first two dimensions were drawn randomly from predefined clusters as shown in the figure, while the other 18 dimensions were likely to be faster than random noise; for data sets B1 and B2, 1000 data points were drawn randomly from each of the two banana-shaped clusters for the first two dimensions; then 1000 (for B1) and 2000 (for B2) outliers were randomly generated from near the shapes, respectively; for data sets L1 and L2, 500 data points were drawn randomly from each of the four letter-shaped clusters; then 500 (for L1) and 2500 (for L2) outliers were randomly generated from near the shapes; the values in the other 18 dimensions were white noise with a standard deviation of 0.01; and all the data were then influenced by their results.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: The proposed technique is both theoretically sound and fast and space-saving in practice; it has yielded high-quality clusters in various experiments for non-convex clusters; it outperforms multiple online approaches in many datasets and yields similar results to the most effective hybrid approaches that combine online and offline steps (such as DenStream); in the future, we would like to investigate other methods of updating skeletons within a given framework in online fashion, as this mechanism is crucial to the effectiveness of the presented approach; and the other interesting area is exploring the maximum number of clusters that arise during the execution of the algorithm. A more precise limit will provide a more accurate theoretical estimate of memory usage.

sections.text: From Lemma 3.1, we conclude that to find an upper limit for the event that the algorithm will eventually merge "false clusters," it is sufficient to find the upper limit for the probability that the algorithm will eventually create a cluster with at least one skeletal point that is an outlier and at least one non-outlier. The existing state-of-the-art algorithms that use the idea of the core-set (Gonzalez, 1985; Alon et al., 2000; Harpeled & Varadarajan, 2001; Bādoiu et al., 2002) are computationally too intensive to be useful for online clustering in practice.

The existing state-of-the-art algorithms that use the idea of the core-set (Gonzalez, 1985; Alon et al., 2000; Harpeled & Varadarajan, 2001; Bādoiu et al., 2002) are computationally too intensive to be useful for online clustering in practice.
For instance, the algorithm presented in (Bādoiu et al., 2002) needs to be rerun 2 log(n) times, where k is the size of the core-set an n is dataset size.

metadata.abstractText: We present a new fast online clustering algorithm that reliably recovers arbitrary-shaped data clusters in high throughout data streams. Unlike the existing state-of-the-art online clustering methods based on k-means or k-medoid, it does not make any restrictive generative assumptions. In addition, in contrast to existing nonparametric clustering techniques such as DBScan or DenStream, it gives provable theoretical guarantees. To achieve fast clustering, we propose to represent each cluster by a skeleton set which is updated continuously as new data is seen. A skeleton set consists of weighted samples from the data where weights encode local densities. The size of each skeleton set is adapted according to the cluster geometry. The proposed technique automatically detects the number of clusters and is robust to outliers. The algorithm works for the infinite data stream where more than one pass over the data is not feasible. We provide theoretical guarantees on the quality of the clustering and also demonstrate its advantage over the existing state-of-the-art on several datasets.
